loans.name: Mariam

texts.en:
Mariam is a single woman with six children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that does not have electricity or piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.
Mariam has operated a charcoal sales business for the past four years. She sells charcoal retail and from home to her neighbors and passers-by. In addition she has a food vending business that contributes another source of income. Mariam faces the major challenge of seasonality in her business. She hopes to expand her business in the future.
With the 40,000 KES loan, she wants to purchase sacks of charcoal for resale. She decided to join Kiva partner, Yehu, to access loans to improve her business.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of charcoal for resale

loans.name: Concepcion

texts.en:
Concepcion is a 49-year-old married woman from the town of Sto. Niño. She earns a living through farming – in particular, she plants and harvests rice crops. Concepcion has been engaged in farming for many years already and hopes to improve her business and earn a better income.
Concepcion needs additional farm inputs such as fertilizers. She has applied for a loan of 20,000 PHP from KIVA partner, CEVI. Concepcion plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and other farm inputs

loans.name: Bayasgalan

texts.en:
Bayasgalan R. is 47 years old and lives with his wife and two sons in Uvurhangai province, Mongolia. His youngest son attends a local high school. He and his family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent.
Bayasgalan operates a raw material trading and transportation business in his local town. He has been engaged in this business since 2004 after moving to his current town. He purchases a variety of raw materials from the countrysides and transports those products to his local town in order to sell them as a retailer. His wife helps him with the business. He transports loads between Uvurhangai and Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. After years of operation, he has gained much experience as a driver and has built a stable operation. Bayasgalan says, "I want to expand my business further and my dream is to have my own shop in the future." He is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan in order to purchase more coal and wood to sell.

loans.use: To purchase more coal and wood for resale

loans.name: Shirley

texts.en:
Shirley A. is from the village of Mapuroc, San Mateo, Isabela. She is 48 years old, married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Shirley owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector planting and harvesting fruits and vegetables for sale. Shirley has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP per month from these activities.
In 2010, Shirley joined Kiva partner, ASKI, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her first from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

About ASKI
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose is a married woman with five children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that does not have electricity or piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.
Rose has operated a vegetable stall business for the past five years, selling vegetables retail and from home to her neighbors and passers-by. Rose faces the major challenge of high transportation costs in her business. She hopes to open a retail shop in the future.
With her 40,000 KES loan, she wants to purchase green vegetables and potatoes for her vegetable stall. She decided to join Kiva partner, Yehu, to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase green vegetables and potatoes for her vegetable stall

loans.name: Seng

texts.en:
Mrs. Seng O. is married and blessed with four school-aged children. She operatesher own small trade out of her home by making traditional noodles to sell to buyers who come to purchase directly from her house. Her husband works on their farm fields.
In order to earn more income for supporting her family, Mrs. Seng O. would like to borrow some funds to buy a few small pigs for feeding and then selling on for profit. Her own funds are not sufficient so therefore Mrs. Seng O. is applying for a loan from Kiva. The rest of the loan will be used to purchase seeds in order to start to work on her dry-season rice field.

loans.use: To buy a few small pigs and seeds for her dry-season rice field

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more repair supplies and tools

loans.name: Editha

texts.en:
Editha, 55 years old, is from the town of Sto. Niño. She is married and has eight children. Three of her children still go to school. Editha does her best to sustain her children's education because she wants them to finish college and have bright futures.

Editha is a farmer and she says she has been engaged in farming for almost 26 years already. Her husband, who is also a farmer, helps maintain their rice farm. Editha does her part to keep their farm productive and makes sure to take care of her family.

In need of additional farm inputs, Editha applied for a loan of Php 20,000 from CEVI, a KIVA partner. She will use the loan amount to buy fertilizers and other supplies she needs for their farm. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her children's school fees.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Benedetta

texts.en:
Benedetta is a married woman with eight children; two graduated from school while five still attend school and the youngest one is still too young for school. She owns a house that  has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are school fees and food for the family.

She has operated a goat-sales business buying at the market and selling to her neighbours and passersby. Benedetta faces a major challenge with the high cost of transportation in her business. She hopes to expand and sell wholesale.

With the Kshs 30,000 she wants to purchase goats for sale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to improve her business.

loans.use: To purchase goats for sale

loans.name: Narantsetseg

texts.en:
Narantsetseg B. is 48 years old and lives with her husband and four children in Hovd Province in Western Mongolia. She and her family have lived together in their own apartment for past 5 years. Her older daughter attends university and youngest two daughters both attend a local secondary school.

Narantsetseg operates a machinery parts trading business at the local technical market in her town with the help of her husband. She started her business in 2008 and has built a stable operation since then. Her earnings have enabled her to pay her two children's tuition fees. 

Narantsetseg is a modest and hardworking person. Her main goal is to provide for her children's educations and to help them become a good and responsible persons. In the future, she hopes to expand her business by increasing her working capital. She is requesting a  800,000 MNT loan to buy supplies for her machinery parts trading business.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her machinery parts store

loans.name: Dolgorsuren

texts.en:
Dolgorsuren B. is 47 years old and lives with her husband and two children in Hovd province of Mongolia. She and her family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. Her middle son is university student and youngest daughter attends a local secondary school. 

Dolgorsuren operates a vegetable business in her town with help of her husband. They plant and grow vegetables and sell to customers through the local grocery market in their town. They have been engaged this business since 2004 and have built a stable operation. 

After several years of successful business activity, she used her earnings to pay tuition fees of her sons. Her oldest son has completed his university training and her younger son currently attends university. In the future, she hopes for continued success and wants to build a house and cellar in her yard. 

She is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan to purchase a large amount of vegetables from local growers at wholesale prices.

loans.use: To purchase a large amount of vegetables

loans.name: Jargal

texts.en: Jargal S. is 28 years old and lives with her husband and daughter in Hovd province in western Mongolia. She and her family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. Her daughter attends a local school. Her husband operates a transportation business between local towns using his own minibus. Jargal manages a clothing business in her town. She has been selling a variety of clothing items at the local market since 2006 and has gained significant experience in her trade. She plans to buy a container at the local market and a new minibus for her husband. For the future, Jargal hopes to continue to grow her business and says, "My business goal is to buy a minibus for my husband in the near future." Jargal is a hardworking and optimistic woman. She is requesting a 1,300,000 MNT loan to purchase more winter clothes in order to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase more winter clothes

loans.name: Emma

texts.en:
Emma C. is from the town of Sto. Niño. She is 57 years old and married, and has 5 children. To make a living, Emma plants and harvests rice to sell. Emma is hoping for her harvest to increase.

Emma joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Emma has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Emma is requesting a new loan of 20000 PHP which will be used to buy farm supplies and additional merchandise to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support her family financially.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies and additional merchandise to sell

loans.name: Tuy

texts.en: Tuy Y. is a 34-year-old woman who lives in the province of Kompong Cham, which is the best territory for farming. She is married with six children, all of whom are single. Two of her children work in different jobs and they share their salary with her every month. Tuy Y. owns a few farms that she inherited from her grandmother. She grows various crops on them. She is currently raising a peanut crop and she estimates that she will harvest it within the next two months when the plants mature. Her husband helps her to grow crops. Tuy Y. just rented her neighbor's farmland to use for more peanut crops, but she has not yet planted crops on it. Tuy Y. is applying for a loan to pay for the rental of the new land and to hire a machine to plow it. The remainder of the loan will be used for hiring labor to clean grasses in and around her farmland.

loans.use: To help raise peanut crops.

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn C. is from the town of Sto. Niño. She is 28 years old and has a 5-year-old child. Evelyn is involved in farming. She plants and harvests rice crops. Evelyn also decided to put up a sari-sari (general) store to help with her family's daily needs. She sells a variety of different products at her store. 

Evelyn is a member of CEVI, a partner of KIVA. She applied for a loan of PHP 8000 which will be used to buy farm supplies and additional merchandise to sell at her store. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the businesses to support her family financially.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies and additional merchandise to sell

loans.name: Launh

texts.en: There are many Cambodians who make a living as rice cultivators; one of them is Mrs. Launh T. who has been working in this sector since 1988. She and her husband grow rice on their own farmland that they inherited from their grandparents. From this business they can generate an income of around US$2.50 per day. This humble couple has two single children who are students. This rice-growing season, the family planted rice two months ago and their rice is growing well. To improve her farming business, Mrs. Launh T. needs a loan from Kiva in order to purchase fertilizers and seeds for doing dry-season rice-field.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and seeds for doing dry-season rice-field.

loans.name: Haykaz

texts.en:
Haykaz P. is 53 years old.  He lives in Kapan city with his wife and his son.  His two daughters are married and live separately from their parents. 

For about 15 years Haykaz and his wife have been engaged in clothes, shoes and household goods trading.  At the same time, Haykaz drives a taxi; so thanks to his occupations he provides for his family's needs and was able to marry off his daughters.  Haykaz works in his shop without any days off and he says he has a lot of regular customers.  He buys merchandise from Yerevan and sells it in Kapan market. 

Haykaz is asking for a 700,000 AMD loan to buy house slippers, underclothes, pajamas and high boots to resell. Haykaz has already received 9 loans from Nor Horizon.

loans.use: To buy house slippers, underclothes, pajamas and high boots to resell.

loans.name: Flor

texts.en:
52-year-old Flor C. is from the town of Sto. Niño.  She is married and has 6 children.  Two of her children are both in college.  Flor and her husband are working to ensure and sustain their children's education.

Flor is a farmer and has been planting and harvesting rice crops for more than 30 years.  Most of the people in her town are farmers who also sell rice. Flor wants to serve better quality rice and that's why she works hard to supply her farm with quality seeds and fertilizers.

Flor also joined CEVI, an MFI in the Philippines and a KIVA partner.  She says that her previous loans helped a lot in maintaining her farm.  She is now requesting for a loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to buy seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs.  She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's living condition.

loans.use: To buy seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: This Kiva borrower is an 18-year-old single man living with his parents in Lebanon. He has a technical school education and a strong and proven business intuition. He owns a successful hardware store which sells equipment and different materials. Today, he is requesting a loan of $800 from Kiva's partner, Ameen s.a.l., to expand his enterprise and purchase additional merchandise to reinforce his sales and increase his profit. His business is vital to help his father with the family's expenses. In the future, he hopes to develop his business so he can support and employ additional workers from the area and create a source of income for others.

loans.use: To expand his enterprise and purchase additional merchandise

loans.name: Chhoeun

texts.en: Chhoeun V. was born in 1966 and is married. She has two children who both attend public school. To earn a living, Chhoeun V. cultivates a rice crop with her husband. She currently lacks farming supplies to help support her work on the farm, so she would like a loan from Kiva. She will use the loan to pay someone to plow her dry-season rice field and to purchase seeds and fertilizers to help her crops grow well.

loans.use: To pay plowing fee, to purchase seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Guillerma

texts.en:
34-year-old Guillerma C. is from the town of Sto. Niño.  Guillerma is a farmer and plants rice crops.  She sells her harvest to the market and sometimes gives some portion to her family.  Guillerma works hard to improve her business.  She hopes to save for her future and be able to continue helping her family grow this business.

Guillerma joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Guillerma has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI.  Guillerma is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to buy fertilizers and other farm inputs.  She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and other farm inputs

loans.name: Bakbu's Group

texts.en:
Bakbu N. is the leader of this group.  She is a resident of Tashkomu, a small town in the south of Kyrgyzstan.  She is 48 and married.  Her husband earns money by providing welding services.  Bakbu has five children, two of them are in school.  

In order to earn money to cover family expenses she sews Kyrgyz national blankets, pillows and carpets.  She has been doing it for five years. Her monthly profit is 8,000 soms.  Bakbu applied for the loan because she needs money to purchase fabrics and materials needed for sewing. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). 

MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase fabrics and materials needed for sewing.

loans.name: Oksana

texts.en:
Oksana is married with two children who are 8 and 5 years old. She raises tomatoes, cucumbers and radishes in her own greenhouses. She started this business twelve years ago. Hard work and persistence helped her to develop it well. Today she has five large greenhouses that provide a stable income for her family.

Oksana is requesting a loan of 12,000 UAH to purchase seeds, fertilizers and new film for her greenhouses. She needs to purchase these inventories now to have good crops in the Spring. This business is the only source of income for her family.

loans.use: to purchase seeds, fertilizers and film for the greenhouses

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: This Kiva borrower is a 27-year-old single man living with his parents and three siblings. He is from Lebanon. He has been working as a baker for over ten years. His freshly prepared goods are enjoyed by members of his village and neighboring towns. With his loan of US $1200, he will develop his business and increase his productivity by upgrading his equipment. In the long term, he is planning to continue expanding his business and he is positive about the coming year. His bakery is an important source of income for his family. Lebanon has many pastry shop and bakeries and it is easy to buy fresh goods in one’s village or neighborhood. In the future, he is planning to develop his operation by opening a restaurant on the same lot where his bakery is located.

loans.use: To upgrade his equipment

loans.name: Henry

texts.en:
Henry S. is from the town of Santo Niño. He is 47 years old and married, and he has one child. To make a living, he plants and harvests rice to sell. Henry joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI.

Henry is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve his family's living conditions.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Jeanne D'arc

texts.en:
Jeanne is 37 years old and is married.  She sells a variety of goods in her general store.  These include items used in daily life, such as body lotion, sugar, soap, biscuits, etc. She has been running this small store for one year.

Jeanne has requested a loan to purchase foodstuffs, such as rice, sugar, Irish potatoes and beans for her shop.  Jeanne would like to use the profit to continue to grow her business.

loans.use: To purchase rice, sugar, Irish potatoes and beans

loans.name: Begaiym's Group

texts.en:
Begaiym O., 40, is the leader of this group. She is a widow, and she is bringing up a fourteen year old son, who studies at school. Six years ago, in order to cover family expenses, and with the initial investment of 20,000 KGS, Begaiym started to sell fruits and vegetables in the local market. Now she makes about $153 per month.  With money received from the loan, Begaiym wants to expand her business and purchase more fruits and vegetables to sell.  In the future she dreams of building a store near her house. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Micro-finance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Micro-finance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year.

To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase more fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Clementine

texts.en:
Clementine is 32 years old and is married with two children who are 6 and 11 years old.   Her husband works as a driver.  She lives in the Gasabo district where she owns a well-organized shop, selling a variety of goods. Her business is open from 5am until 8pm every day and she has been in this business for six years.

Clementine has requested this loan to purchase a large stock of goods to sell.  She will use any profits to continue to develop and improve her business.

loans.use: To purchase more goods to sell in her shop.

loans.name: San

texts.en: San S., 29, is a local rice grower who has been farming on her land for over four years. For additional income, San S. raises a few pigs in a stall at her home. She is married to Nait Noeurn, age 36, who assists with the farming business. This couple has four children who are living at home because they are studying in school. Because the pig-raising business is a very profitable one for San S. and her family, San S. has requested a loan in order to buy additional feed and piglets to raise. With the remaining money, she will buy tobacco stock which she will sell at profit.

loans.use: To buy additional feed and piglets and tobacco stock

loans.name: Sozui's Group

texts.en:
Sozui A. is the leader of this group. She is the resident of Tup, a small town in the Isykul region. She is 54 years old and divorced. Sozui has three sons and a daughter. Her sons work in construction and her daughter attends school. Ten years ago, with an initial investment of 15000 soms, Sozui started to breed cattle. By reselling cattle, she makes 3000 soms per month. With the money from this loan, Sozui wants to purchase two cattle and resell them at the higher price after fattening. In the future, she wants to open a pharmacy.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase cattle

loans.name: Vin

texts.en:
Vin V., age 61, lives in the province of Kompong Cham, which is the best territory for farming. Vin V. is a married woman who is devoted to her two children, one of whom is single, studying in school and dependent on her care. The other one is married, but still living under her roof. 

Vin V. grows various crops on her farmland. Now, she is planting rice and corn. Her husband helps her to grow crops. The coming rainfall is good for planting her crop, so Vin V. is looking for a loan to purchase fertilizers, insecticides, and corn seed for additional planting. 

Vin V. and her husband appear in the photo.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers, insecticides, and corn seed for planting.

loans.name: Marie Rose

texts.en:
Marie Rose is 31 years old, married and has 2 children. Marie Rose’s husband is a technician and they both work hard to provide for their family. Marie Rose owns a small shop where she sells hardware and spare parts for construction. This is her 10th successful month in business! 

Marie Rose has requested a loan to buy more construction supplies to sell in her store. She plans to use any profits she makes to reinvest in her business.

loans.use: To buy more hardware and construction supplies

loans.name: Noruzkan's Group

texts.en:
Noruzkan B. is the leader of this group. She is a resident of Toktogul.  She is 55 and married. Her husband is engaged in cattle breeding. They have two sons, both married and living separately with their families. Ten years ago, with an initial investment of 30,000 soms, Noruzkan rented a place and started to sell Kyrgyz national cloth, carpets and dishes. Her monthly profit is 8,000 soms.  With money received from the loan, she wants to increase the turnover of her business and purchase more cloth and carpet for sale. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase cloth to sell

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: This Kiva borrower is a 43-year-old married man and the father of two children. He is from Lebanon. He has been working as a home electrician for over 15 years. He works on a freelance basis upon request of his clients. Over the years, he has been able to meet his family needs, especially raising his two children who still attend school. Today he is requesting $1,100 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to renew his tools and purchase scaffolding for his newest project. In the future, he is planning to open an electrical store in addition to his work.

loans.use: To renew his tools and purchase scaffolding for his newest project

loans.name: Sauda

texts.en:
Sauda is 33 years old and is married with one child who is 9 years old. Sauda provides secretarial services. She has been in this business for about five years and she works from 8 a.m. until 7 p.m. every day except Saturday. She currently employs two people.

Sauda has requested a loan to purchase additional items such as a photocopier, more printers and paper.  If successful, Sauda hopes to continue building a secure future for her family by reinvesting any profits into her business.

loans.use: To purchase more equipment for the business

loans.name: Baara Group

texts.fr:
Baara  est un regroupement de dix femmes toutes mariées dans des familles conjugales traditionnelles élargies avec leurs frères, sœurs, co-épouses, enfants et époux. Elles ont   une moyenne d’âge de 26 ans, de 3 enfants et résident dans le quartier Heremakono-Nord, de la ville  de BOUGOUNI,(troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).  Elles se sont connues par des relations de commerce. 
Dans l’intention d’acheter plus de produits, elles ont décidé d’adhérer à  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso. Elles sont à leur deuxième prêt de groupe, le prêt précédent a été correctement remboursé. 
Avec ce prêt MARIAM D., la présidente du groupe, compte acheter une grande quantité de condiments alimentaires de différentes sortes auprès des grossistes. Elle effectue sa vente au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Avec ce prêt elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 30.000 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisé dans l’activité et l’autre partie dans les frais d’éducation de leurs enfants.
texts.en:
Baara is a gathering of 10 women, each married in a traditional extended family with their brothers, sisters, co-wives, children and husband. They have a median age of 26, an average of 3 children and live in the Heremakono-Nord neighborhood of the city of Bougouni (in the third administrative district in the Republic of Mali). They met one another through business connections.

With the intention of buying more goods, the women of Baara decided to join the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso. They are on their second group loan, the previous loan having been properly repaid.

With this loan, Mariam D., the group's president, intends to buy a large quantity of different sorts of spices from wholesalers. She makes her sales in cash and on credit to a client base of men and women.

With this loan, Mariam plans to make a monthly profit of 30,000 CFA francs, a portion of which will be used for the business and the rest for the education expenses of their children.

loans.use: Buying spices

loans.name: Akbarali

texts.en:
A. Akbarali a farmer. He learned to grow different kinds of vegetables from his parents. Now that Akbarali has his own family, he works his best to increase his yield to support the needs of his little children. Akbarali is 23 years old and has 2 children. He depends on his harvest for the future of his family. Almost all of his harvest is saved for family consumption, while the remainder is sold in the market by his wife. Akbarali is requesting a loan of 6000 Somoni. He will use the loan to buy the necessary fertilizers and seeds for his crop. His loan will give Akbarali better harvest. In this way, he will have more to give to his family. 

 
More about Tajikistan and IMON International

It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

loans.use: Purchase seeds and mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Jeanne

texts.en:
Jeanne is 46 years old and she is married with six children between the ages of 6 and 23 years old. Jeanne owns a restaurant in the Muhima Sector of the Gasabo District. She has been in this business for around eight years. The hours of her restaurant are from 5:30 am until 10 pm every day.

Jeanne has requested a loan to help her to paint the walls of her restaurant as well as her own house. In addition, she will purchase some equipment for the restaurant, such as saucepans, new plates etc. With this loan, Jeanne hopes to improve the quality of service in her restaurant.

loans.use: To paint her restaurant and buy saucepans and new plates.

loans.name: Abdujabor

texts.en:
Abdujabor’s economic activity is agriculture, to which he has dedicated himself for several years. He is married and the father of 5 children. Abdujabor learned farming business from a young age and now has a lot of experience. His business requires a lot of effort, which is why he dedicates himself to growing potatoes, onions, carrots, etc. This requires a lot of exposure to the sun as well as moving the product long distances. Abdujabor is requesting a loan from IMON International to invest in technological assistance in cultivation. With this loan he will be able to succeed and have better opportunities for the sale of his products after the harvest.

loans.use: Purchase seed and mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Afouchata

texts.fr:
Née le 31 Août 1987  à Sikasso, Afouchata B. est une femme mariée et mère de 2 enfants résidant avec son époux et leurs enfants dans une grande famille traditionnelle élargie à Bougoula Ville Sikasso ( troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Après mener beaucoup d’activités sans succès, Afouchata s’est initiée à l’activité de vente de pagnes et d'encense il y a environ 7 ans. 
 Dans le souci de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décida d’intégrer l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il y a environ deux ans. Après un prêt solidaire (prêt du groupe) dans une association des femmes de son quartier, elle est à son deuxième prêt individuel, le précédent ayant été correctement remboursé. Ce deuxième prêt lui permettra d’acheter 5 balles de pagnes et  quelques paquets d' encense à Bobo Dioulasso (Burkina Faso) et sur place à Sikasso qui seront vendus de façon ambulante à une clientèle composée essentiellement de femmes.
Elle envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 100 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales et payer les intérêts de son prêt.
texts.en:
Afouchata B. was born on August 31, 1987 in Sikasso. She is a married woman and the mother of two children. She lives with her husband and their children in a large traditional extended family in Bougoula Town Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali.)

After having unsuccessfully tried a few activities, seven years ago Afouchata learned to sell pagnes [colorful traditional wrap around fabric] and incense.

In order to better meet her ever-increasing customers’ demand, two years ago she decided to join Soro Yiriwaso. After a solidarity loan (group loan) in a neighborhood woman’s association, she is on her second individual loan. The first one was fully reimbursed. This second loan will allow her to buy five bales of pagnes and a few packets of incense in Bobo Dioulasso (Burkina Fasso) and locally in Sikasso. They will be sold door to door to customers who are mostly women.

With this loan, she is planning on making a monthly profit of 100, 000 Francs CFA that will be mostly used to increase her working capital, covering the family’s expenses and to pay back her loan.

loans.use: To purchase bales of pagnes

loans.name: Yuldoshali

texts.en:
K. Yuldoshali is 43 years old, married and has 4 children. He and his wife work on a small farm. He has been a farmer since he was young and now that he has a family he is especially motivated to succeed. Yuldoshali plants several hectares of potato, onion and other vegetables. Yuldoshali is very grateful for his job, especially since it is so profitable. As long as his farmland is well-tended he can harvest all year long. His main difficulty is in dealing with the insects that effect his crops. This is Yuldoshali's second loan from IMON International and he wants to purchase seed and fertilizer for his crop. The loan should greatly improve Yuldoshali’s income and his family's living standards.

loans.use: Purchase seed and mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Mariam

texts.fr:
Née le 23 Décembre 1979 à Bamako (capitale du Mali), Mariam B. est mariée et mère 5 enfants. Elle réside dans une famille nucléaire avec son époux à Wayerma I, un des  quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Madame Mariam B. après avoir mené beaucoup d’activités sans succès,  s’est initiée à cette activité d’achat et vente  des pagnes Wax,  de chaussures, de  Tissus brodés, de concentrée de tomate il y a environ cinq ans. Elle mène son activité à son domicile et de façon ambulante dans la ville de Sikasso où elle est beaucoup sollicitée de sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses produits. 
Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il y a maintenant cinq ans avec laquelle elle a bénéficié  5 prêts solidaires dans un association des femmes de son quartier (Association DANAYA de Wayerma I). Tous ses prêts solidaires ont été tous correctement remboursés ce qui lui a valu un premier prêt individuel  qui fut également bien remboursé. 
Ainsi, elle sollicite ce deuxième  prêt individuel  pour acheter à Lomé (république du Togo) 25 paires de chaussures différentes, 10 pièces de pagnes Wax, 4 complets de tissus brodés et 10 complets de napperon. Ses marchandises sont vendues en détail de façon ambulante au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée essentiellement de femmes.
Elle envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 130 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales et payer les intérêts de son prêt.
texts.en:
Mariam B. was born on December 23 1979 in Bamako (capital of Mali). She is married and the mother of five children. She lives in a nuclear family with her spouse, in Wayerma I, one of the working-class neighborhoods of the town of Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali.)

After having unsuccessfully pursued various activities, five years ago Mrs. Mariam B. learned the business of purchasing and selling Wax pagnes [colorful traditional wrap around fabric], shoes, embroidered fabric and tomato concentrate. She is conducting her business form her home and door-to-door in the town of Sikasso. Her customers hold her in very high demand because of the quality of her products. Five years ago she decided to join the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwasso in order to meet her ever-increasing customers’ demand. She has already received five group loans with a woman’s association from her neighborhood (Wayerma I Danaya Association). All her group loans have been fully reimbursed which got her a first individual loan that was also fully reimbursed.

She is requesting a second individual loan to buy 25 pairs of shoes, 10 pieces of Wax pagnes, 4 suits of embroidered fabric and 10 sets of doilies. Her merchandise will be sold retail door to door for cash and on credit to customers who are mostly women.

With this loan she is planning on making a monthly profit of 130,000 Francs CFA. It will be mostly used to increase her working capital, cover the family’s expenses and pay her loan.

loans.use: To purchase Wax pagnes, shoes, embroidered fabric and doilies.

loans.name: Islombek

texts.en:
K. Islombek is 33 years old and lives in Shahrituz. He is married and has 4 children. Islombek is the only breadwinner in the family and he is a hard-worker.  For many years Islombek has managed his own café where he serves his clients and also takes orders for meal preparation without home delivery. Islombek is trying to have fresh foodstuff and tasty meals in his café and to ensure his clients have the possibility to eat, to have a rest and make their necessary purchases. Islombek wants to increase the number of his clients, so he decided to increase the size of his café. Now he needs $3000 USD to build a new roof on his café.

loans.use: Expanding his business in order to earn more money.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more bags of used shoes

loans.name: Ruzikhol

texts.en:
T. Ruzikhol is 41 years old. She is married,  the mother of 6 children and lives with her husband in Shahrituz, Tajikistan. She and her husband, together, put all their effort toward working very hard on their farm, growing wheat, onion and a variety of fresh vegetables. Early every morning, the couple’s children collect the produce and sell it at a market. 

Ruzikhol is requesting a loan to purchase more fertilizer, insecticide, and seeds for their farm. You are the one who will determine their success and play an important role in their business’s growth. Ruzikhol has gained a reputation for responsibility with her financial obligations and for keeping her word. We are happy to have another opportunity to assist her with the operation of her business.

loans.use: Purchase seeds and mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Boubacar

texts.fr:
Monsieur Boubacar C. âgé de plus de 35 ans,  marié et père de deux enfants. Il habite le quartier Kaboïla I-Kélétiguila, le centre ville de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du mali) .
Il exerce ce métier depuis maintenant six ans après avoir mené plusieurs activités sans succès. Vu l’augmentation de sa clientèle et que ses ressources financières propres ne pouvant satisfaire les attentes de cette clientèle, il  jugea utile de venir auprès de l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso pour lui solliciter un premier prêt. 
Ce présent prêt individuel lui permettra d’augmenter son fonds propre afin d’acheter 10 paires de chaussures “Ferardine”, 5 complets de veste “Abacos”, 5 paires de souliers, une douzaine de ceintures, 15 pantalons de qualité différentes, 10 chemises différentes, etc. Il s’approvisionne à Bamako afin de les revendre de façon ambulante entre les différentes structures professionnelles de Sikasso ville et souvent jusqu’à Baguinéda sur la route de Ségou..
Ce présent prêt lui permettra de réaliser un bénéfice de 120 000 FCFA qui servira à augmenter son fonds de commerce mais également d’honorer ses engagements à l’égard de Soro Yiriwaso puis couvrir d’autres dépenses familles.
texts.en:
Mr. Boubacar C. is over 35 years old, married and the father of two children. He lives in the neighborhood of Kaboïla I-Kélétiguila, in the center of the town of Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali.)

He has been practicing his activity for six years after having lead several unsuccessful activities. His customer base is increasing and his own financial resources cannot meet the demand of these customers, so he decided to request a first loan and join the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwasso.

This current individual loan will allow him to increase his working capital in order to buy 10 pairs of shoes “Ferardine”, 5 “Abacos” suit jackets, 5 pairs of dress shoes, a dozen belts, 15 pair of pants of various quality, 10 shirts etc… He gets his supplies in Bamako in order to sell them door-to-door between the various professional entities in Sikasso town and often as far as Baguinéda on the road to Ségou.

This current loan will allow him to make a monthly profit of 120,000 Francs CFA. It will be mostly used to increase his working capital, but also to honor his commitment to Soro Yiriwaso and to cover other family expenses.

loans.use: to purchase clothing

loans.name: Hassina

texts.en:
Hassina is 42 years old and is married with six children between the ages of 9 and 25 years old. Hassina owns a small business selling vegetable oil and rice in the Kicukiro market.  Hassina’s business is well organized and she employs one other person to help her.  She decided to start her small store, as these items are much in need in her neighborhood 

Hassina has requested a loan to purchase new products such as rice, salt, sugar and other foodstuffs needed by her customers. This loan will allow her to attract new clients, helping her to obtain more profits. With the extra income, Hassina will save money for the future.

loans.use: To buy new products such as salt, sugar and rice

loans.name: Panji

texts.en:
Y. Panji is 60 years old. He is married with 6 children. Panji and his whole family are farmers. He plants wheat, onion, potato and other vegetables. He tells us that he comes from a farming family and that he does very well financially because he takes good care of his land. At the same time he raises cattle. 

Thanks to his savings, Panji was able to arrange the marriage of his elder son. His sons are now adult and are his biggest supporters. They help him in anything they can and help take good care of the crops. A client is on the far right side of the picture. With this loan, Panji would like to expand his irrigation system which is fundamental when it comes to farming. The loan will greatly improve his income and his family's living standards.

To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To expand his irrigation system

loans.name: Fatoumata Modibo

texts.fr:
Madame Fatoumata Modibo S. a  environ 46 ans et est mère de cinq enfants (2 garçons et 3 filles). Elle vit avec son époux et leurs enfants à Wayerma I, un des  quartiers périphériques de la ville de Sikasso.
Madame Fatoumata Modibo S. après avoir mené beaucoup d’activités sans succès, s’est initiée à cette activité d’achat et de vente d’habits, de produits de beauté et divers articles depuis plus de sept ans. Elle mène son activité au grand marché de Sikasso. Maintenant, elle veut profiter de ce prêt de Soro Yiriwaso pour devenir une grande commerçante au niveau du marché où elle opère afin de satisfaire sa clientèle dont la plupart est constituée de femmes.
Après avoir correctement remboursés ses trois prêts précédents, elle est à son quatrième prêt individuel, qu’elle compte utiliser pour acheter 5 complets de tissus brodés, 6 cartons de pommade de qualités différentes, 5 sacs à main pour les femmes, 4 cartons de parfum de qualités différentes, 10 glacières, 5 cartons de déodorants, 2 cartons de savon de beauté, 5 paires de chaussures, des trousseaux pour nouveaux nés, etc. Elle s’approvisionne à Bamako, Bobo Dioulasso (république du Burkina Faso) et souvent à Lomé (république du Togo). 
Avec ce prêt, elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 200 000 FCFA. Ces bénéfices réalisés lui permettront de résoudre l’essentielle de ses dépenses, contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en: Madame Fatoumata Modibo Sibide is about 46 years old and is mother to five children (2 boys and 3 girls). She lives with her husband and their children in Wayerma I, one of the suburbs of the town of Sikasso.  After numerous unsuccessful business ventures, Madame Fatoumata Modibo S. started this business more than seven years ago to buy and sell clothes, beauty products and various other products. She does this at the main market in Sikasso. Now she would like to use this loan to become a big seller in the market in which she operates and to meet the needs of her clients who are mainly women. After successfully paying back her three previous loans, she is on her fourth individual loan, which she plans to use for buying 5 suits made of embroidered fabric, 6 boxes of various creams, 5 women's handbags, 4 boxes of various perfumes, 10 coolers, 5 boxes of deodorant, 2 boxes of beauty soap, 5 pairs of shoes, layettes, etc. She gets her supplies in Bamako, Bobo Dioulasso (Burkina Faso) and often in Lomé (Togo). With this loan, she expects to make a monthly profit of 200000 FCFA. She will use these profits to pay for basic expenses, family expenses and repaying her loan. She will invest any remaining profits back into her business.

loans.use: To buy clothes, beauty products and cooking utensils.

loans.name: Kansé

texts.fr:
Monsieur  Kansé C. a plus de 31 ans, marié et père de deux enfants. Il réside avec sa famille à Sanoubougou I, un des quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso ( troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Monsieur C. après avoir mené plusieurs activités sans succès, s’est initié au commerce qui lui a souri et il dispose de nos jours de deux boutiques: une pour les Prêt à Porter et une pour l’Alimentation, à la gare routière de Sikasso. Avec plus de 10 ans d’expérience dans le domaine, il est beaucoup sollicité de sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses produits. 
Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, il décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il y environ trois année. Après avoir correctement remboursé ses deux prêts précédents, il est à son troisième prêt individuel.
 Ce troisième prêt lui permettra d’acheter 15 chemises différentes, 17 pantalons de qualité différentes, 15 paires de chaussure différentes (Soulier, Ferardine, etc.), 5 complets de veste, 10 Tee-Shirt, 5 complets de sous-vêtement, etc. Il s’approvisionne auprès de commerçants grossistes à Bamako avant de les revendre en détail à une clientèle composée généralement de voyageurs et surtout de routiers.
Il envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 250 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales et payer les intérêts de son prêt.
texts.en:
Mr. Kansé C. is more than 31 years old, married and the father of two children. He lives with his family in Sanoubougou I, a working-class neighborhood in the city of Sikasso (in the third administrative district in the Republic of Mali).

Mr. C., having headed several business without success, has found the business that has smiled on him and he now has two boutiques: one for ready-to-wear clothing and one for food, at the bus station in Sikasso. With more than 10 years of experience in the field, he is highly sought after by his customers for the quality of his wares.

In order to satisfy his continually growing customer base, he decided to join the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso three years ago. After having properly repaid his two previous loans, he is on his third individual loan.

This third loan will allow Mr. C. to buy 15 assorted shirts, 17 pairs of pants of various qualities, 15 assorted pairs of footwear (sturdy shoes that cover the whole foot, Ferardine shoes, etc.), 5 suits, 10 t-shirts, 5 sets of underwear, etc. He purchases his stock from the wholesalers in Bamako before re-selling it at retail to a customer base mostly made up of travelers, particularly truck drivers.

With this loan, Mr. C. hopes to make a monthly profit of 250,000 CFA francs, which will mainly be used to grow his business, contribute to the family expenses and pay the interest on his loan.

loans.use: Buying clothing.
